ratings.comment: He stared directly at the eclipse.

Good lecturer, an hour and 15 minutes is not boring. I really learned a lot about the subject in Professor Owen's class. The grade consists of 2 midterms and 1 final. The grading is fair, and you have chances to save your grade even if you bombed one.

I really enjoyed prof Owens. Since he has a Phd and Law degree it was great to hear from him as a prospective law student. His lectures are interesting and engaging but he does ask for a lot of participation. He is a pretty tough grader, but he gives very thorough feedback so you can improve. Grade is 5 memos, 6 discussion posts, and participation.

Owens was a phenomenal professor. He's very clear on course expectations & was accessible when students needed help. I feel this was the most real-life applicable class I've ever taken. Not denying this class is a lot of work, but it's 600 level class so it's harder than a strictly undergrad class. I can't emphasize enough how great the class is.
Very good lecturer. Course is organized clearly. Lecture is essential

Administrative Law is a dry and boring subject, but he found ways to show the wider implications of agency action and the administrative state. Genuinely good teacher. Don't skip class/find a friend who takes good notes. Slides arnt posted, and the content you need to know goes beyond the readings in the syllabus

Admin law is supposed to be dry and confusing, but Professor Owens makes sure it isn't. His lectures are really engaging and he's lowkey hilarious. You're definitely going to have to study hard for the exams but if you show up to lecture and pay attention, you should have no issues passing the class.

Owens managed to make Admin Law, a usually boring topic, into something I really wanted to learn. He's eccentric but really loves what he does and breaks the material down to easy to understand concepts. Advice: for tests, focus on the overarching concepts and how to apply them, he'll make you apply them to made-up examples.

Ryan Owens covers a lot of complicated topics in an easy to understand way. His lectures are really engaging. Provides extra credit and you can get away without the textbook, but dont miss a lecture because all of the material for exams comes from his lecture.

Professor Owens is by far my favorite professor that I've had at UW. He challenges you and expects you to work hard, but it's always with the intention of trying to make you better. His lectures are engaging (and hilarious) and it's really hard to be bored during his class. He gives you an amazing amount of feedback as well. HIGHLY recommend.
waaaaaaay too much effort for an undergrad class. Expects you to be a licensed lawyer essentially
Professor Owens' grading is arbitrary and his expectations unclear. He also interrupts students when they are speaking for no apparent reason.

I loved Owens and he gave clear, engaging, knowledgable lectures about the Supreme Court. Once in a while, the material was dry but he is HILARIOUS so lectures went fast. He's professional but still approachable and relaxed. Two midterms and a final. Exams are extremely fair. I would recommend this class/ Prof Owens.

Not an easy professor, but not difficult either! His lectures are very good, and he is willing to stop and answer questions. I didn't do a lot of readings, but he does a good job explaining in class. However, his assigned readings are not horrible and they are what he's going to over in class, not just useless readings. I'd take his class again!

Great professor, one of my favorites at the university. EXTREMELY intelligent and very helpful. Definitely cares about his students learning and doesn't assign things to make your life difficult. Very fair exams.

Good class, not the greatest teacher but an interesting topic. By the end of the semester seemed to be running out of things to work with. However overall a good class, interesting topic, and testing was fair.
Prof Owens is very knowledgable and passionate about the Supreme Court. Had quite a bit of reading, but it was all relevant.
